Editor's Choice paper Evaluation of enantiopure and non-enantiopure Co(III)-salen catalysts and their counter-ion effects in the hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) of racemic epichlorohydrin Rebecca E. Key a Krishnan Venkatasubbaiah b Christopher W. Jones a b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0400, USA b School of Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0100, USA ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Biomolecular Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0400, USA. Tel.: +1 404 385 1683; fax: +1 404 894 2866. Graphical abstract Highlights ► HKR catalysis via molecular Co(III)-salen systems was studied. ► Co(III)-salens with 50% enantiopure ligand and nucleophilic counter-ions were used. ► This approach did not lead to enantioselective HKR catalysis. ► Counter-ion scrambling between Co centers occurred under reaction conditions. ► A novel way to regenerate deactivated polymer-supported Co(III) complexes was found. Hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) resolves racemic epoxides using water as the nucleophile and is most often catalyzed by chiral Co(III)-salens. 1 1 Co(III)-salen=(R,R)-(N,N′)-bis(3,5-di-tert-butylsalicylidene)-1,2-cyclohexanediaminocobalt(III). Previous studies have shown that the counter-ion of the Co(III)-salen has a direct effect on rate of HKR; when catalyzed by a 50:50 mix of (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-OH and (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-SbF6, the fastest HKR rates occurred. It has further been shown that the enantioselectivity is primarily associated with the reaction of (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-OH on the activated epoxide. Based on the aforementioned origin of selectivity, a catalyst containing a 50:50 mix of ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-OH and (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen-SbF6 could, in principle, give high activities and enantioselectivities for HKR comparable to a mixed counter-ion system containing both ( R , R )-Co(III)-salens. Here, a series of experiments are described that demonstrate that highly selective catalysis is only achieved using 100% enantiopure ligand, and mixtures of ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen and (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen yield lower activity and selectivity. Control experiments demonstrate this is due to rapid counter-ion scrambling under reaction conditions, precluding the possibility of effectively co-utilizing enantiopure (expensive) and racemic (inexpensive) catalysts with differing counter-ions. The mechanistic investigations resolving the counter-ion scrambling are consistent with the currently accepted mechanism for catalysis, involving cooperative activity of two Co(III)-salen species that activate the epoxide and water in the reaction. Keywords Co(III)-salen Chirality Counter-ion exchange Polymer resin-support Hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) 1 Introduction Metal-salen catalysts are now ubiquitous in catalysis and organic synthesis [1–3], being used in a variety of enantioselective reactions, including olefin epoxidation [4–6], epoxide ring-opening [7–9], nitroaldol reactions [10], and conjugate additions [11], as recent examples. The hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) 2 2 Abbreviations: HKR: hydrolytic kinetic resolution Co(III)-salen: (R,R)-(N,N′)-bis(3,5-di-tert-butylsalicylidene)-1,2-cyclohexanediaminocobalt(III). of racemic epoxides is a well-established technique to resolve epoxides, specifically terminal epoxides, into a single enantiomer via a ring-opening reaction using water as the nucleophile (Scheme 1 ) [7]. The HKR of terminal epoxides has attracted widespread interest for a number of reasons. From a synthetic chemistry perspective, the strained, reactive, and three-membered ring functionality makes enantiopure epoxides a useful chiral building block for numerous reactions [12]. In addition, the coproduct of the reaction, a chiral diol, can be a useful building block as well, being used, for example, in the synthesis of active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) [12,13]. Also with respect to pharmaceutical significance, macrocyclic Co(III)-salen-PF6 has been used as a catalyst to synthesize the chiral drugs (R)-mexiletine and (S)-propranolol via HKR [14]. From a catalysis science perspective, the Co(III)-salen catalyzed HKR reaction has become a useful test-bed for the development of supported catalysts that enhance cooperative catalysis, as the HKR reaction is now the prototypical cooperative bimolecular reaction catalyzed by a metal–ligand complex (vida infra) [15]. The HKR of epoxides was originally developed by Jacobsen, using chiral Co(III)-salen-benzoate complexes [7] [Co(III)-salen=(R,R)-(N,N′)-bis(3,5-di-tert-butylsalicylidene)-1,2-cyclohexanediaminocobalt(III)] as the precatalyst (Fig. 1 ) [16]. Using Co(III)-salen-X (X=nucleophilic counter-ions, such as Cl−, −OAc) complexes, Jacobsen and Blackmond showed that the reaction typically follows a second-order, cooperative bimetallic pathway (where two cobalt centers participate in the rate-determining step of the reaction) [16–19]. In this proposed mechanism, one Co(III)-salen (presumed to have the original counter-ion, X) activates the electrophilic epoxide, while the other Co(III)-salen (presumed to have an OH− counter-ion) activates the nucleophilic water (Scheme 2 , red pathway) [16,18,19]. Nielsen et al. demonstrated that the nucleophilicity of the Co(III)-salen counter-ion (Fig. 1) [16,17] had a direct and important effect on the rate of HKR [16]. At low catalyst loadings, it has been said that there is a less-selective, monometallic pathway that competes with the bimetallic pathway [20]. Taking the nature of the Co(III)-salen counter-ion into consideration, Jain et al. suggested that a less selective, monometallic pathway (Scheme 2, blue pathway) [17] couples with the bimetallic pathway (Scheme 2, red pathway) [16] when Co(III)-salens with highly non-nucleophilic counter-ions are present in the reaction. For the bimetallic pathway, the hypothetical Co(III)-salen-OH 3 3 The Co(III)-salen-OH is a hypothetical species, first proposed by Nielsen et al [16]. This active species has yet to be isolated or conclusively characterized. Kemper et al. used in situ solution NMR and quantum chemical calculations to study coordination, conformational, and electronic properties of Co(III)-salens to better understand the enantioselectivity of HKR [21]. They determined that for the bimetallic transition state exemplified by the two Co(III)-salens in HKR, the nucleophilic Co(III)-salen-OH exists as a pentacoordinated, high spin, paramagentic complex, and the Co(III)-salen-X (X≠OH) that activates the epoxide exists as a hexacoordinated, low spin, diamagnetic complex [21]. The two Co(III)-salens are aligned in a “head-to-tail” orientation [22]. Due to this orientation, the Co(III)-salen-OH can attack one epoxide enantiomer over the other [21]. Recently, Vinck et al. proposed that a small fraction of the Co(III)-salen-OAc species in HKR is a Co(III)-bound phenoxyl radical that is formed via air oxidation of Co(II) with acetic acid present (Scheme 3) [23]. This radical, which has one to two acetates ligated to the complex, is proposed to have formed via a two-electron, two-proton reduction of oxygen to hydrogen peroxide, thus producing a delocalized phenoxyl radical that is stabilized by the bulky tert-butyl groups located at the ortho- and para-positions of the phenolate [23]. The radical was characterized by pulsed and continuous-wave electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), as well as resonance Raman (RR) [23]. is formed in situ from Co(III)-salen-X (X≠OH) via a nucleophilic attack (by the counter-ion X) on the epoxide (Scheme 2, black pathway) [16]. If X is a good nucleophile, such as Cl−, the counter-ion will rapidly add to the epoxide in the black pathway, and water is suggested to produce the hypothetical Co(III)-salen-OH. With an accumulation of Co(III)-salen-OH occurring in the HKR, the catalytic activity decreases because Co(III)-salen-OH is a poorer Lewis acid than Co(III)-salen-X (X≠OH) [16]. If X= −OTs, HKR catalysis is highly efficient, as counter-ion addition is reversible, because Co(III)-salen-OTs is not suggested to completely convert to Co(III)-salen-OH [24]. If X is non-nucleophilic, such as SbF6 −, there should be no nucleophilic attack of the counter-ion on the epoxide, thus no generation of Co(III)-salen-OH [16]. As a result, a cooperative, bimetallic pathway is not suggested to take place to a significant extent (Scheme 2, red pathway) [16], and the HKR is suggested to be catalyzed primarily via a less selective, monometallic pathway (Scheme 2, blue pathway) [17]. Based on the above mechanistic picture, it has been demonstrated that with a 1:1 ratio of Co(III)-salen-OH and Co(III)-salen-SbF6, the fastest rates for the HKR occur, with the rapid formation of the bimetallic transition state, thus allowing the enantioselective, bimetallic pathway to dominate [16,17]. As mentioned previously, the salen catalysts used for HKR are typically enantiopure, which is required to successfully produce a highly enantiopure product. However, Nielsen et al. suggested that each epoxide enantiomer bound to Co(III)-salen-X with the same affinity [16]. This suggests that the binding of an epoxide to Co(III)-salen-X is not a strongly enantiodiscriminating step and that the high enantioselectivity of the HKR is predominantly due to the selective reaction resulting from the nucleophilic Co(III)-salen-OH attacking one of the Co(III)-salen-X-epoxide complexes [16]. This is consistent with the suggestion that the monometallic path (Scheme 2, blue pathway) [17] is less enantioselective than the cooperative pathway (Scheme 2, blue+red pathway) [16,17], although the still moderate enantioselectivity achieved using only non-coordinating counter-ions suggests (i) there is some selectivity associated with epoxide binding, or (ii) the bimetallic pathway still operates when only trace amounts of Co(III)-salen-OH species are produced [16]. Based on these findings, it might be inferred that the chirality of the Co(III)-salen-X (X=non-nucleophilic counter-ion) is less important or even unimportant in determining the enantioselectivity of the HKR reaction. To probe this hypothesis, we evaluate here the HKR of epoxides using salen complexes constructed from a variety of counter-ions (Cl−, OH−, SbF6 − and −OAc) using both enantiopure and racemic salen ligands. If each complex is stable under reaction conditions, a catalyst containing a 50:50 mix of ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-OH and (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen-SbF6 may give good activity and enantioselectivity for HKR of epoxides that is comparable to a catalyst containing a 50:50 mix of ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-OH and ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-SbF6. This 50% decrease in use of the more expensive chiral ligand [25] could provide significant practical advantages for Co(III)-salen catalyzed HKR reactions. To this end, mixed ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-OH and (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen-SbF6 catalysts are explored here for the HKR of racemic epichlorohydrin. This approach is not found to yield highly enantioselective catalysis, and the causes for the reduced selectivity are enumerated here, shedding further insight into the nature of the HKR reaction pathways. 2 Experimental 2.1 General Reagents were purchased from commercial vendors and used as received unless otherwise stipulated. All starting materials were dried under high vacuum before use. Styrene and para-dichlorobenzene were dried over calcium hydride and purified by vacuum distillation before use. Divinylbenzene (DVB) was washed with 5% NaOH (2×) and deionized water (2×) to remove polymerization inhibitors, and then it was dried with anhydrous MgSO4 prior to use. 1H NMR spectra were obtained using a Varian Mercury spectrometer (400MHz); the chemical shits were expressed in ppm and are referenced to the corresponding residual nuclei in the deuterated solvents. FT-IR spectra were obtained using a Bruker Vertex 80v (Ram II) by dispersion of samples in a KBr pellet. Elemental analyses (EA) on samples were performed by Columbia Analytical Services, Tuscon Laboratory (Tuscon, AZ, USA). The conversion of racemic epichlorohydrin and enantiomeric excess (ee) of (S)-epichlorohydrin were determined by a Shimadzu 17A GC with an FID and Chiraldex γ-TA column (40m×25mm×0.25μm). Either para-dichlorobenzene or mesitylene was used as an internal standard. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of (R,R)- and (±)-trans-Co(III)-salen-Cl (1 and 3, respectively) Catalysts 1 and 3 were prepared according to previously published procedures [16]. In a separatory funnel, (R,R)- or (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen-OTs was dissolved in dichloromethane (1g catalyst to 40mL dichloromethane). The organic layer was washed three times with equal volumes of saturated aqueous NaCl and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic layer was put under reduced pressure and concentrated to obtain a dark green solid; this solid was then resuspended in n-pentane, vacuum filtered, and dried under high vacuum overnight to obtain catalyst 1 or 3. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400MHz) δ 7.81 (s, 2H), δ 7.45 (s, 2H), δ 7.42 (s, 2H), δ 3.63–3.51 (m, 2H), δ 3.09–2.98 (m, 2H), δ 2.03–1.95 (m, 2H), δ 1.95–1.82 (m, 2H), δ 1.72 (s, 18H), δ 1.61–1.53 (m, 2H), δ 1.28 (s, 18H). 2.2.2 Synthesis of (R,R)- and (±)-trans-Co(III)-Salen-SbF6 (2 and 4, respectively) Catalysts 2 and 4 were prepared according to previously published procedures [16,17]. First, 1.2equiv. of AgSbF6 was dissolved in ∼55mL dichloromethane in a round-bottom flask equipped with a stirbar and wrapped in aluminum foil. Then, 1equiv. of (R,R)- or (±)-trans-Co(II)-salen was added to the AgSbF6/dichloromethane solution. The flask was immediately stoppered, and the reaction was stirred overnight at room temperature in the dark. The dark green solution was then filtered (in darkness) through two fresh pads of celite. The filtered solution was then concentrated under reduced pressure and then rinsed with n-pentane. The dark green catalyst was dried overnight under high vacuum. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400MHz) δ 7.81 (s, 2H), δ 7.45 (d, J=2.5Hz, 2H), δ 7.42 (d, J=2.7Hz, 2H) δ 3.60–3.56 (m, 2H), δ 3.08–3.01 (m, 2H), δ 2.01–1.95 (m, 2H), δ 1.93–1.83 (m, 2H), δ 1.72 (s, 18H), δ 1.61–1.52 (m, 2H), δ 1.28 (s, 18H). 2.2.3 Synthesis of polymer resin-supported (R,R)-CO(III)-Salen-OAc (8) Catalyst 8 was prepared according to previously published procedures [26–28]. First, 1equiv. of 7 was put into a 25mL pear-shaped flask equipped with a triangular stirbar. Dichloromethane was then added to the flask (1mL per 5mg 7). Subsequently, 5equiv. of glacial acetic acid was added until the solid changed from orange to light brown. The reaction mixture was then stirred at room temperature open to air for 30min. The dichloromethane and excess acetic acid was removed using a rotovap (T <60°C). The recovered catalyst 8 was dried for 1h under high vacuum and immediately used for HKR reactions. For EA, catalyst 8 was dried under high vacuum overnight. 2.3 Synthesis of styrene/DVB resin Styrene/DVB resin was synthesized according to previously published procedures [27]. A two-neck round-bottom flask equipped with a stirbar and reflux condenser was purged with nitrogen. Then, 1equiv. of styrene and 5equiv. DVB were added to the flask, and the reaction mixture was heated under nitrogen for 36h at 80°C. After cooling to room temperature, the white solid was then washed several times with methanol and dichloromethane. After filtation, the resin was allowed to dry overnight under high vacuum. 2.4 HKR of racemic epichlorohydrin A pear-shaped flask equipped with a stirbar was charged with the respective catalyst at the appropriate loadings (0.25 or 0.5mol%). The flask was then immersed in a water bath to keep the reaction temperature constant. Next, 1equiv. of racemic epichlorohydrin was added to the flask, followed by internal standard (para-dichlorobenzene or mesitylene). After stirring briefly, 2.5μL of the mixture was passed through a silica plug and washed with diethyl ether prior to the catalytic reaction. Deionized water (0.6equiv.) was then added to start the reaction. For homogeneous catalytic studies, 2.5μL samples were taken until 99% ee or a constant, maximum % ee was reached. For reactions using polymer resin-supported catalysts, 2.5μL samples were taken for 4h. 4 4 Time it took to determine that 99% ee of HKR with catalyst mix 2 + 8 was reached. Samples from all reactions were passed through a plug of silica gel to remove the catalyst and washed with diethyl ether before GC/FID analysis. 2.5 Catalyst recovery Upon completion of HKR reactions with polymer resin-supported catalysts, the reaction mixture was poured onto a frit to isolate the solid catalyst, and this catalyst was washed with dichloromethane until the liquid filtrate became clear and colorless. The solid catalyst was dried under high vacuum overnight and then analyzed via EA and FT-IR. The recovered filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure (T <60°C) to recover the homogeneous catalyst from the reaction. This catalyst was also dried overnight under high vacuum and analyzed via EA. 3 Results and discussion As noted above, previous work has suggested that only the ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-OH complex generated from ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-X containing a nucleophilic counter-ion plays a key role in the enantiodiscriminating step in the HKR [16]. To this end, an array of reactions was first explored evaluating the ligand chirality and role of the counter-ion in the HKR of racemic epichlorohydrin (Tables 1 and 2 , respectively). Specifically, both the (±)- trans -salen and ( R , R )-salen ligands were used in combination with the non-nucleophilic SbF6 − counter-ion, and the nucleophilic Cl− counter-ion, which has been suggested to rapidly convert to the OH− counter-ion under reaction conditions [16] (Table 1). 3.1 HKR of racemic epichlorohydrin The conversion of racemic epichlorohydrin and the resulting enantiomeric excess (ee) of (S)-epichlorohydrin were monitored by GC/FID using a chiral capillary column. The results are collected in Table 1. In the first entry, the use of ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-Cl (1) at 0.25mol% catalyst loading is demonstrated to be an active and selective catalyst over one use, providing a high turnover frequency (TOF) and good enantioselectivity of unreacted epichlorohydrin, achieving 99% ee at 52.1% conversion (perfect selectivity would give a conversion of 50%). Catalyst 1 gave an initial turnover frequency of 1.78min−1 and displayed a selectivity marked by a very high k rel 5 5 See Table 1 for definition of k rel [29]. of >99. By comparison, at the same catalyst loading, ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-SbF6 catalyst (2) gave a much lower initial rate (0.89min−1) and is also less enantioselective, with a k rel of 8.2 (Table 1, entry 2). These results are consistent with the reaction pathways described above, with the catalyst in entry 1 rapidly proceeding down the selective pathway shown in Scheme 2 (red/blue pathway) [16], and the catalyst in entry 2 being shuttled through the less selective blue pathway (Scheme 2) [17]. In entry 3, a 50:50 mixture of the two counter-ions on the enantiopure ligand (catalysts 1 and 2) was employed at 0.5mol% catalyst loading. This combination also gave a selective catalyst, and was the most active of all runs, as exemplified in the literature [16,17]. Next, reactions were run with a 50:50 mixture of enantiopure and racemic salen ligand. First, in entry 4, the reaction results from the use of ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-Cl (1) and (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen-SbF6 (4) are described. If the enantiospecificity of the reaction was largely determined by the chirality of the complex with the nucleophilic counter-ion, in this case complex 1, this reaction should proceed with identical selectivity as entry 1 in the absence of counter-ion exchange. However, as shown in the table, this catalyst combination was actually less active and selective than all the reactions described in entries 1–3, suggesting either the mechanistic hypothesis above is incorrect or other factors were important. In entry 5, catalysts 2 and 3 [( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-SbF6 and (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen-Cl, respectively] were used, with opposite pairing of ligands and counter-ions as the previous case (entry 4). Based on the mechanistic hypothesis described above, this catalyst should be the least selective of the combinations in the absence of counter-ion exchange. However, as shown in Table 1, the catalyst combination, while also unselective, gave nearly identical results to entry 4. These last two runs, in combination, are consistent with the occurrence of rapid scrambling of counter-ions under reaction conditions, as such scrambling should produce the same average combination of catalysts in both entries 4 and 5. If this scrambling were to occur, the above results would then remain fully consistent with the overall mechanistic picture described in Scheme 2 [16–19] and remove the possibility of lowering the cost of the reactions by using a combination of enantiopure and racemic ligands. Therefore, the counter-ion exchange hypothesis was explored in more detail to support or refute this hypothesis. 3.2 Co(III)-salen-X counter-ion exchange One way to determine if counter-ion exchange is present in a mixed counter-ion Co(III)-salen system is to separate and isolate one Co(III)-salen-X species from the other for direct characterization; this can best be explored by immobilizing one of the Co(III)-salens onto a support. Previously, Co(III)-salen-triflates have been immobolized onto gold colloids [30], and our group has immobilized metallosalens on silica [31], soluble polymers [26,32], polymer resins [27,31], and oxide-supported polymer brushes [33]. (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-OAc (8) was supported on a polymer resin with a flexible linker, as these salens have previously been used to give good catalytic rates and selectivities, as reported by our group (Scheme 4 ) [26–28]. This catalyst was combined with (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-SbF6 as a soluble homogeneous catalyst (Fig. 1, catalyst 2) [17]. Catalysts 2 (Fig. 1) [17] and 8 (Scheme 4) [26–28] were prepared according to previously published procedures [17,26–28] and characterized by elemental analysis (EA) (Table 2, entries 1, 3, 4). HKR reactions were run with the combination of resin-supported (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-OAc (8) and homogeneous (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-SbF6 (2), along with the appropriate control reactions (Table 2, entries 1–4). Following HKR, the resin-supported salens were recovered via vacuum filtration for analysis by EA and FT-IR. If counter-ion exchange occurred during the reactions, the spent supported catalysts should exhibit an increased Sb/Co ratio, and an Sb-F stretch near 660cm−1 should be apparent in the FT-IR spectrum of the recovered solid, which was initially Sb-free [34]. For the HKR reaction with a catalyst mix of 2 (Co(III)-salen-SbF6) and 8 (supported Co(III)-salen-OAc), the supported spent catalyst, 8, when analzyed by EA, had an Sb/Co ratio of 0.26 (Table 2, entry 5). Though the Sb/Co ratio observed for this catalyst mix is less than the Sb/Co ratio of fresh catalyst 2 that is fully oxidized to Co(III)-SbF6 (1.02, Table 2, entry 1), it is greater than the Sb/Co ratio of fresh and spent catalyst 8, which has no SbF6 − counter-ion (<0.05 and <0.04, Table 2, entries 3 and 4, respectively). This suggests that some SbF6 − counter-ion from homogeneous catalyst 2 has exchanged with the counter-ion from supported catalyst 8. To verify the presence of SbF6 − in spent catalyst 8, the solid was examined by FT-IR. A peak at 661cm−1 associated with an Sb-F stretch (Fig. 2 , dot-dashed line) clearly suggests the presence of SbF6 − in the spent solid 8, whereas fresh and spent catalyst 8 from regular reactions without catalyst 2 do not have this peak (Fig. 2, solid and dotted line, respectively). Analysis of the filtrate of the HKR reaction using catalyst mix 2 and 8 (which includes homogeneous (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-SbF6) gave an Sb/Co ratio of 0.60 (Table 2, entry 6), indicating thtat there is a decrease in SbF6 − relative to the fresh catalyst 2 (Table 2, entry 1). Based on the data presented in Table 2 and Fig. 2, it can be concluded that there is a degree of counter-ion exchange occurring, where SbF6 − is transferred from the homogeneous (R,R)-Co(III)-salen 2 to the resin-supported (R,R)-Co(III)-salen 8, which originally included −OAc. This exchange is further exemplified when an HKR reaction is run with homogeneous (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-SbF6 and resin-supported (R,R)-Co(II)-salen, which is orange in color (catalyst mix 2 and 7, respectively). A brown solid catalyst was recovered from this reaction, indicative of a Co(III)-salen species supported on the resin. The Sb/Co ratio for this catalyst was 0.34 (Table 2, entry 7), which is greater than the ratio that would be expected for catalyst 7, which has no counter-ion coordinated to the Co center (<0.01, Table 2, entry 2). This suggests that either the SbF6 − species are transferred onto the supported Co(II) species, oxidizing it to Co(III)-SbF6, or homogeneous Co(III)-salen-SbF6 species are trapped within the resin. In this case, the spent resin material, 7, also shows an Sb-F stretch at 661cm−1 in its FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 3 , dotted line), whereas the spectrum of the fresh catalyst 7 does not show this peak (Fig. 3, solid line). The light brown filtrate from the HKR reaction using catalysts 2 and 7 gives an Sb/Co ratio of 0.58 (Table 2, entry 8), indicative of a partial SbF6 − transfer from homogeneous (R,R)-Co(III)-salen to resin-supported (R,R)-Co(II)-salen. To determine whether significant amounts of SbF6 − may become trapped within the polymer resin without reacting with a Co-salen center, HKR reactions were run using catalyst 2 and a polymer resin constructed of 1:5 crosslinked styrene/DVB, which does not include any salen species. In evaluating the EA data, the Sb content in both fresh and spent styrene/DVB resins were found to be negligible (Table 2, entries 9 and 10). Also, there was no Sb-F stretch found at 661cm−1 in the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 3, dot-dashed line). In addition, the dark green filtrate of the HKR reaction with the salen-free styrene resin and 2 had a Co/N ratio of 0.49 and an Sb/Co ratio of 0.91 (Table 2, entry 11), indicating that nearly all of complex 2 was recovered (Table 2, entry 1). Since an increase in Sb/Co ratio, as well as the presence of the Sb-F stretch is observed in the spent catalysts upon exposure to catalyst 2 and minimal to no amount of catalyst 2 becomes trapped within the salen-free polymer resin, it can be concluded that the Sb species found in spent catalyst from entires 5 and 7 of Table 2 are indicative of the prevalence of counter-ion exchange occurring between SbF6 − and −OAc. Thus, the similar reactivity seen in Table 1, entires 4 and 5 demonstrates that rapid counter-ion exchange occurs between the Co(III)-salen species during catalysis and, therefore, mixed chiral-racemic ligand systems cannot be used to reduce the cost of HKR reactions. It should further be noted that the counter-ion scrambing is consistent with the mechanism of Nielsen et al. [24]. 4 Conclusions The potential of combining chiral and racemic ligands in the enantioselective HKR of epoxides based on the mechansitic hypotheses of Nielsen et al. was explored [16]. Based on the currently accepted mechanism, high activity and enantioselectivity might be achieved in reactions catalyzed with by 50% enantiopure ligand with a counter-ion designed to make the salen complex a nucleophile-delivering complex (e.g. OH−) and 50% racemic ligand with a counter-ion designed to make the salen complex a Lewis acidic, electrophilic complex (e.g. SbF6 −). In this work, it was shown that such experiments do not lead to highly selective catalysts due to counter-ion scrambling between the Co centers. The counter-ion scrambling hypothesis was supported by control experiments using polymer-supported Co-salen species and the associated kinetic evidence, FT-IR spectra, and elemental analysis results. This study also showed that oxidation of a Co(II) species on a polymer support can be promoted via contact with a homogeneous Co(III) species, which suggests a method for catalyst regeneration after deactivation by counter-ion loss [28]. coredata.dc:description: Hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) resolves racemic epoxides using water as the nucleophile and is most often catalyzed by chiral Co(III)-salens. 1 1 Co(III)-salen=(R,R)-(N,N′)-bis(3,5-di-tert-butylsalicylidene)-1,2-cyclohexanediaminocobalt(III). Previous studies have shown that the counter-ion of the Co(III)-salen has a direct effect on rate of HKR; when catalyzed by a 50:50 mix of (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-OH and (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-SbF6, the fastest HKR rates occurred. It has further been shown that the enantioselectivity is primarily associated with the reaction of (R,R)-Co(III)-salen-OH on the activated epoxide. Based on the aforementioned origin of selectivity, a catalyst containing a 50:50 mix of ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen-OH and (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen-SbF6 could, in principle, give high activities and enantioselectivities for HKR comparable to a mixed counter-ion system containing both ( R , R )-Co(III)-salens. Here, a series of experiments are described that demonstrate that highly selective catalysis is only achieved using 100% enantiopure ligand, and mixtures of ( R , R )-Co(III)-salen and (±)- trans -Co(III)-salen yield lower activity and selectivity. Control experiments demonstrate this is due to rapid counter-ion scrambling under reaction conditions, precluding the possibility of effectively co-utilizing enantiopure (expensive) and racemic (inexpensive) catalysts with differing counter-ions. The mechanistic investigations resolving the counter-ion scrambling are consistent with the currently accepted mechanism for catalysis, involving cooperative activity of two Co(III)-salen species that activate the epoxide and water in the reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Evaluation of enantiopure and non-enantiopure Co(III)-salen catalysts and their counter-ion effects in the hydrolytic kinetic resolution (HKR) of racemic epichlorohydrin
